review.title: Characterisation of speech diversity using self-organising maps
review.abstract: We report investigations into speaker classification of larger quantities of unlabelled speech data using small sets of manually phonemically annotated speech. The Kohonen speech typewriter is a semi-supervised method comprised of self-organising maps (SOMs) that achieves low phoneme error rates. A SOM is a 2D array of cells that learn vector representations of the data based on neighbourhoods. In this paper, we report a method to evaluate pronunciation using multilevel SOMs with /hVd/ single syllable utterances for the study of vowels, for Australian pronunciation.

metadata.title: Characterisation of speech diversity using self-organising maps

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 2.02 092v 1 [cs.C L] 23 Jan 2017Flinders University tom.anderson @ flinders.edu.au, david.powers @ flinders.edu.au.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The Kohonen Speech Typewriter [1] is a semi-supervised method consisting of Self-Organising Maps (SOMs) that achieves low phoneme error rates. A SOM is a 2D array of cells that learn vector representations of the data based on neighborhoods. In this article we report on a method for assessing pronunciation using multi-level SOMs with / hVd / monosyllabic expressions for the study of vowels according to [2] (for Australian pronunciation).

sections.heading: 2. Methodology
sections.text: We used 18 / hVd / words from AusTalk, an Australian language research corpus collected from speakers of Australian English [3]. To investigate the sensitivity of our phonetic model to dialect, the system was trained using a subset of manually annotated data (phonemes and start / end points) from three other speakers, General Australian (21 speakers), educated Melbournians (21 aged 25-34) or speakers of Chinese (14), and the resulting labeled card was used to separate the unlabeled SOM unit 25x25 using all audio windows from the unlabeled data.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text: Frequently confused phonemes (on the first map) were identified using a greedy method based on high diagonal values in the confusion matrix of the base map: • vowel group 1: / oI / (hoyd) and / o: / (horde) • vowel group 2: / e / (head), / e: / (hairy), / 3: / (herd), / I / (hidden) and / I @ / (heard) • vowel group 3: / 5 / (hud), / æO / (howd), / æI / (hade), / 5: / (hard), / Ae / (hidden), / O / (hod) and / @ 0 / (hode) 1MATLAB scripts are available to authors on request. Scripts for MFCCs were mixed up by mathlabcentral / fileexchange / 32849-htk-mfcput.The Chinese vocal method was compared with the vowel method, whereby 1 was the most frequent.

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text: The aim of the experiments carried out in this paper was to investigate the general ability of marked data to show characteristics of the dialect in the unlabelled language of Australians of Chinese background and educated Melbournians in general versus Australians in general. Results compete with the original phonetic typewriter results and show effectiveness with 39 characteristics of MFCC vectors. There is an opportunity to improve these in context, but for the future direction of this research we are more interested in characterising differences between the three groups.
